name: methylarray-clinical-ewas
title: DNA Methylation Array: Clinical EWAS Analysis
description: Epigenome-wide association study (EWAS) pipeline for clinical methylation array data. Analyze Illumina methylation arrays to discover differentially methylated positions (DMPs) and regions (DMRs) associated with disease, treatment response, or clinical phenotypes.
content:
ğŸ§¬ DNA Methylation Array: Clinical EWAS Analysis

Discover Epigenetic Biomarkers in Clinical Studies

Epigenome-wide association studies (EWAS) use DNA methylation arrays to identify epigenetic changes associated with disease, environmental exposures, clinical outcomes, and treatment responses. This pipeline provides comprehensive analysis of Illumina methylation array data from clinical cohorts, including quality control, normalization, cell type deconvolution, and statistical analysis to identify differentially methylated probes (DMPs) and regions (DMRs).

ğŸ¯ What is EWAS?

Epigenome-wide association studies (EWAS) examine DNA methylation patterns across hundreds of thousands of CpG sites genome-wide to:

  • ğŸ” Identify disease biomarkers: Discover methylation changes associated with disease diagnosis or progression

  • ğŸ’Š Predict treatment response: Find epigenetic markers that predict therapeutic outcomes

  • ğŸ§ª Understand disease mechanisms: Reveal epigenetic dysregulation in pathological states

  • ğŸ“Š Clinical stratification: Classify patients into molecular subtypes for precision medicine

  • ğŸŒ Environmental exposures: Detect methylation changes from toxins, diet, or lifestyle factors

ğŸ”¬ Supported Illumina Array Platforms

This pipeline supports all major Illumina methylation arrays:

  • âœ“ EPIC v2 Array: Latest platform with ~935,000 CpG sites (recommended for new studies)

  • âœ“ EPIC v1 Array: Industry standard with ~850,000 CpG sites (MethylationEPIC BeadChip)

  • âœ“ 450K Array: Legacy platform with ~450,000 CpG sites (HumanMethylation450)

  • âœ“ 27K Array: Original platform with ~27,000 CpG sites (HumanMethylation27)

The pipeline automatically detects your array type from IDAT files and applies appropriate annotation and filtering.

ğŸ“‹ Input Requirements

1. IDAT Files (required)

Raw methylation array data consists of paired IDAT files for each sample:

  • Red channel: SampleID_R01C01_Red.idat

  • Green channel: SampleID_R01C01_Grn.idat

These binary files contain raw fluorescence intensities from the array scanner.

2. Sample Sheet (required)

CSV file mapping samples to clinical metadata:

Sample_Name,Sentrix_ID,Sentrix_Position,condition,age,sex,batch
Patient_001,203901230056,R01C01,case,65,M,1
Patient_002,203901230056,R02C01,control,62,F,1
Patient_003,203901230057,R01C01,case,58,M,2
Patient_004,203901230057,R02C01,control,60,F,2

Required columns:

  • Sample_Name: Unique sample identifier

  • Sentrix_ID: Array chip barcode (from IDAT filename)

  • Sentrix_Position: Position on chip (e.g., R01C01)

  • condition: Primary experimental variable (case vs control, treated vs untreated)

Optional but recommended:

  • age, sex: Demographics for cell type estimation and covariate adjustment

  • batch: Technical batch information for batch effect correction

  • cell_type: If samples are from different tissues or sorted cells

ğŸ“Š Comprehensive Analysis Pipeline

1. Quality Control & Preprocessing

  • ğŸ“ˆ Read IDAT files: Import raw fluorescence data using minfi

  • ğŸ” QC metrics: Assess sample quality, detection p-values, bisulfite conversion

  • âŒ Sample filtering: Remove failed samples based on QC thresholds

  • ğŸ¯ Control probes: Evaluate array performance using built-in controls

2. Normalization & Correction

  • âš–ï¸ Quantile normalization: Correct for technical variation between samples (preprocessQuantile)

  • ğŸ”§ Functional normalization: Alternative method using control probes (preprocessFunnorm)

  • ğŸ“Š Beta/M-values: Calculate methylation values (beta: 0-1 scale, M: log2 ratio)

  • ğŸ§¹ Batch correction: Remove technical batch effects while preserving biological signal

3. Probe Filtering & Quality Control

  • âŒ Cross-reactive probes: Remove probes with off-target binding using DNAmCrosshyb

  • ğŸ§¬ SNP probes: Filter probes overlapping common genetic variants

  • âš§ï¸ Sex chromosome probes: Remove X/Y probes or analyze separately

  • ğŸ” Detection p-value filtering: Remove poorly detected probes (p > 0.01)

  • ğŸ“‰ Low-variance probes: Optional filtering of non-variable CpG sites

4. Cell Type Deconvolution (Blood Samples)

  • ğŸ©¸ Cell composition estimation: Estimate proportions of blood cell types (T cells, B cells, monocytes, granulocytes, NK cells)

  • ğŸ“Š Houseman method: Reference-based deconvolution using cell-specific methylation signatures

  • ğŸ”§ Adjustment: Correct for cell type heterogeneity in differential methylation analysis

5. Differential Methylation Analysis

Differentially Methylated Positions (DMPs)

  • ğŸ¯ Probe-level analysis: Test each CpG site for association with condition

  • ğŸ“Š Linear models: Account for covariates (age, sex, cell type, batch)

  • ğŸ“ˆ Effect sizes: Calculate methylation differences (delta beta values)

  • ğŸ”¬ Statistical significance: FDR-adjusted p-values for multiple testing correction

Differentially Methylated Regions (DMRs)

  • ğŸ§¬ Regional analysis: Identify genomic regions with coordinated methylation changes

  • ğŸ“ Bump hunting: Detect clusters of differentially methylated CpG sites

  • ğŸ¯ Gene-centric DMRs: Focus on promoters, gene bodies, CpG islands

  • ğŸ“Š Regional statistics: Combine evidence across multiple probes for robust detection

6. Biological Annotation & Interpretation

  • ğŸ§¬ Gene annotation: Map CpG sites to nearest genes and genomic features

  • ğŸ“ Genomic context: Classify probes (promoter, gene body, intergenic, CpG island, shore, shelf)

  • ğŸ”¬ Functional enrichment: Pathway analysis of genes with differential methylation

  • ğŸ“Š UCSC tracks: Generate browser tracks for visualization

ğŸ“Š Results & Outputs

Quality Control Reports

  • ğŸ“ˆ QC plots: Detection p-values, bisulfite conversion, signal intensities

  • ğŸ¨ PCA plots: Sample clustering and batch effect visualization

  • ğŸ“Š Density plots: Beta value distributions before/after normalization

  • ğŸ” Sex prediction: Verify sample sex matches metadata

  • ğŸ©¸ Cell type composition: Estimated proportions of blood cell types

Differential Methylation Tables

  • ğŸ“‹ DMP table: All tested CpG sites with statistics (p-value, FDR, delta beta, gene annotation)

  • ğŸ¯ Top DMPs: Significant probes meeting FDR and effect size thresholds

  • ğŸ§¬ DMR table: Differentially methylated regions with genomic coordinates

  • ğŸ“Š Annotated results: Gene names, chromosomal locations, functional context

Visualizations

  • ğŸŒ‹ Volcano plots: Visualize effect size vs statistical significance

  • ğŸ”¥ Heatmaps: Hierarchical clustering of top DMPs across samples

  • ğŸ“ Manhattan plots: Genome-wide view of differential methylation

  • ğŸ“Š QQ plots: Assess test statistic distributions and inflation

  • ğŸ¨ Beta value plots: Sample-level methylation at individual CpG sites

Processed Data Matrices

  • ğŸ“Š Normalized beta values: Quality-controlled methylation matrix for downstream analysis

  • ğŸ“ˆ M-values: Log2-transformed values for statistical modeling

  • ğŸ” Filtered probes: Clean dataset after removing problematic probes

ğŸ§ª Clinical Applications

Cancer Epigenetics

Identify tumor-specific methylation changes, classify cancer subtypes, discover prognostic biomarkers, and detect early cancer signatures in liquid biopsies.

Cardiovascular Disease

Find methylation markers associated with heart disease risk, atherosclerosis progression, and response to cardiovascular medications.

Neurological Disorders

Discover epigenetic changes in Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, schizophrenia, autism, and neurodevelopmental disorders.

Immunology & Inflammation

Study methylation in autoimmune diseases (RA, lupus, IBD), chronic inflammation, and immune cell dysfunction.

Aging & Longevity

Develop epigenetic clocks, predict biological age, identify factors associated with healthy aging and longevity.

Environmental Epidemiology

Detect methylation changes from environmental toxins, air pollution, smoking, diet, and occupational exposures.

Pharmacoepigenomics

Predict drug response, identify resistance mechanisms, discover methylation biomarkers for treatment stratification.

Developmental Origins of Disease

Study early-life exposures, maternal effects, birth cohorts, and developmental programming of adult disease.

âš™ï¸ Key Parameters & Options

Normalization Methods

  • Quantile (default): Robust normalization using subset quantile normalization

  • Functional: Uses control probes to correct for technical variation

  • Raw: No normalization (for method comparison studies)

Statistical Thresholds

  • FDR cutoff: 0.05 (adjustable for sensitivity/specificity trade-off)

  • Delta beta threshold: 0.05-0.20 (minimum methylation difference)

  • Detection p-value: 0.01 (probe quality threshold)

Probe Filtering Options

  • Remove cross-reactive: Recommended (removes ~43K problematic probes)

  • Remove SNP probes: Recommended (removes probes affected by genetic variants)

  • Remove sex chromosomes: Optional (depends on study design)

ğŸ“ˆ Study Design Recommendations

  • ğŸ“Š Sample size: Minimum 20 samples per group for adequate power; 50+ per group ideal

  • âš–ï¸ Balanced groups: Equal numbers of cases and controls improves statistical power

  • ğŸ”„ Technical replicates: Include a few duplicate samples to assess reproducibility

  • ğŸ“¦ Batch design: Randomize samples across array chips to avoid confounding

  • ğŸ“ Metadata collection: Record age, sex, cell counts, medication use, smoking status

  • ğŸ§Š DNA quality: Use high-quality genomic DNA (>500ng, OD 260/280 ~1.8)

  • ğŸ©¸ Sample type: Whole blood most common; specify tissue for appropriate reference panel

â±ï¸ Expected Runtime & Resources

  • â±ï¸ Small study: 30-60 minutes (20-50 samples)

  • â±ï¸ Medium study: 1-3 hours (50-200 samples)

  • â±ï¸ Large cohort: 3-8 hours (200-1000+ samples)

  • ğŸ’¾ Memory: 16-32GB for typical studies; 64GB+ for very large cohorts

  • ğŸ’» Node size: SMALL for pilot studies, MEDIUM for standard cohorts, LARGE for 500+ samples

ğŸ“ Understanding Results

Interpreting Delta Beta Values

  • Î”Î² > +0.20: Strong hypermethylation in cases (20% increase)

  • Î”Î² +0.10 to +0.20: Moderate hypermethylation

  • Î”Î² -0.10 to -0.20: Moderate hypomethylation

  • Î”Î² < -0.20: Strong hypomethylation in cases (20% decrease)

Statistical Significance

  • FDR < 0.05: Genome-wide significant (< 5% false discoveries expected)

  • FDR 0.05-0.10: Suggestive association (may warrant validation)

  • FDR > 0.10: Not significant after multiple testing correction

Biological Context

  • Promoter hypermethylation: Often associated with gene silencing

  • Promoter hypomethylation: May indicate gene activation

  • CpG island shores: Frequently show tissue-specific methylation

  • Gene body methylation: Complex relationship with expression (context-dependent)

ğŸ“š Next Steps After EWAS

  1. ğŸ”¬ Validation: Confirm top findings in independent cohort using pyrosequencing or targeted sequencing

  2. ğŸ§¬ Functional studies: Test whether methylation changes affect gene expression (integrate with RNA-seq)

  3. ğŸ¯ Mechanism: Investigate what causes methylation changes (genetic variants, environment, disease process)

  4. ğŸ“Š Pathway analysis: Use enrichment tools (GREAT, Ingenuity, GOseq) to identify affected biological pathways

  5. ğŸ¥ Clinical utility: Develop biomarker panels, risk scores, or diagnostic tests

  6. ğŸ“– Literature: Search PubMed for known associations with your top differentially methylated genes

  7. ğŸ—ƒï¸ Public databases: Compare findings to EWAS Catalog, EWAS Atlas, MethBank

ğŸ” Quality Control Checklist

After analysis, verify these quality metrics:

  • âœ“ Sample call rate: > 98% probes detected per sample

  • âœ“ Detection p-values: < 1% probes with p > 0.01

  • âœ“ Bisulfite conversion: > 90% efficiency

  • âœ“ Sex concordance: Predicted sex matches reported sex

  • âœ“ Sample outliers: No extreme outliers in PCA or clustering

  • âœ“ Batch effects: Minimal separation by technical factors in PCA

  • âœ“ Inflation factor: Genomic inflation Î» â‰ˆ 1.0 (no systematic bias)

spec.label: Sample Sheet
spec.name: input
spec.description: CSV file with columns: Sample_Name, Sentrix_ID, Sentrix_Position, condition (and optional: age, sex, batch, cell_type). Maps IDAT files to sample metadata and experimental groups.

spec.label: Output Directory
spec.name: outdir
spec.description: Directory where analysis results, QC reports, differential methylation tables, and visualizations will be saved

spec.label: Array Type
spec.name: array_type
spec.description: Illumina methylation array platform used in your study. The pipeline will auto-detect if not specified, but explicit selection ensures correct annotation.

spec.label: Normalization Method
spec.name: norm_method
spec.description: Method for normalizing methylation data to remove technical variation. Quantile normalization is recommended for most studies.

spec.label: Remove Cross-Reactive Probes
spec.name: remove_crossreactive
spec.description: Remove probes that hybridize to multiple genomic locations. Highly recommended to avoid false positives from off-target binding.

spec.label: Remove SNP-Affected Probes
spec.name: remove_snp
spec.description: Remove probes overlapping common genetic variants (SNPs) that can confound methylation measurements. Recommended for clinical EWAS.

jobConfig.label: System Size
jobConfig.name: system_size
jobConfig.description: Select compute resources based on your cohort size. Start with SMALL for pilot studies (< 50 samples), use MEDIUM for standard cohorts (50-200 samples), LARGE for big studies (200-1000 samples).

options.label: XSMALL (4 CPUs, 15GB RAM) - Testing/nf-core test data
SMALL (8 CPUs, 30GB RAM) - Pilot studies (< 50 samples)
MEDIUM (32 CPUs, 120GB RAM) - Standard cohorts (50-200 samples)
LARGE (64 CPUs, 360GB RAM) - Large cohorts (200-1000 samples)
XLARGE (128 CPUs, 450GB RAM) - Very large cohorts (1000+ samples)
